Reviews.Content: The reason is that, this very system the battery doesn't last longer than 2hrs.Please if possible I need explanation  of  the proble.

Reviews.Title: Ultrabook incredible
Reviews.Author: LEONARDO SOUZA
Reviews.Content: I am Brazilian and I bought this ultrabook in the U.S. and loved it, I refer to all. Very good.

Reviews.Title: More than I expected
Reviews.Author: Jeremy
Reviews.Content: I was planning on just getting the laptop with the charger. Instead I got the full package with a stylus, adapter ports, cleaning pads, etc all in brand new packaging. The computer itself works well, considering that I'm using it to type this message. Thanks

Reviews.Title: perfect
Reviews.Author: michel nascimento
Reviews.Content: I love it, I recommend, it is a lillte expensive, but I am very happy with this product, thanks Asus!

Reviews.Title: Problems with Windows 8
Reviews.Author: PoppyDog
Reviews.Content: Please see my notes for the Netgear PTV3000-100NAS PushTVI like the concept because it allows me to use my TV as a second monitor while at the same time working on the laptop.Since I am not a techie I cannot tell if the issues I am having are caused by the ASUS or the Windows 8 program.  But I will tell you that it the most aggravating piece of equipment I have ever used.

Reviews.Title: Great laptop, with annoying bugs
Reviews.Author: N. E. Hale
Reviews.Content: I love this laptop in a lot of ways, but there are some annoying to downright frustrating issues. The day I got it I walked around the office making the Mac people envious. The double screen element is great for work because I show a lot of powerpoint presentations and can do it across the table now rather than on a projector. I have to tilt it in an uncomfortable way for me when I do this, but that's not a big deal - I can see the presenter mode and that's enough. In other meetings I keep my logo or my client's logo running on the outside screen. I installed Windows Classic Shell to run over Windows 8 within a week.Battery life yes is dismal, but what do you expect for such a small and light laptop with two screens? I bought a backup power source.As mentioned earlier, the auto-brightness is very annoying. Even if you have it on the brightest setting, if the (default) auto-brightness is on, it may dim it and you're unable to make it brighter. You have to disable this, frequently.The main issue that I have is that the internet drops ALL THE TIME, and the wifi signal is possibly less powerful or only handles a lower bandwidth. I can't use it in my bedroom or porch anymore, and can't trust that the internet won't drop at any time. It once dropped in the middle of an online exam. I've now seen this as a known issue on their site, with a possible fix to disable the option to let the network adapter sleep to save power. I've turned that off but am yet unsure of whether it's any better. I know I should have (and still should) call and complain, but I hate the idea of spending fruitless hours on the phone then having to rebuild everything, so have just whined and worked around it so far. They ignore the Facebook page and don't answer any questions sent in that way.Overall a great laptop, but they need to fix some things with it.

Reviews.Title: One Hot Workhorse
Reviews.Author: Walt Nicholson
Reviews.Content: Outperforms my desktop.But I miss the hard drive.Win8 isn't ready for prime time - waiting for substantive update with fingers crossed..Wish both screens were toutchscreen

Reviews.Title: Computer Amazing, AMAZON TERRIBLE!!! DO NOT BUY FROM AMAZON!
Reviews.Author: Mercy C. MccUlloch "mercymildindian"
Reviews.Content: Computer works BETTER than described. If you are a nerd, you can find all the amazing features this computer offers! It's incredible! Pressure sensitive tablet, amazing keyboard and best touch pad ever!DO NOT ORDER FROM AMAZON! They messed up the order and it arrived at least a week later, even though I did one day shipping. This isn't the first time I have had problems with Amazon.

Reviews.Title: Great laptop
Reviews.Author: Lenin
Reviews.Content: Very handy and useful laptop for business use and only con is storage capacity, light weight and great tablet features with windows 8

Reviews.Title: Excellent
Reviews.Author: Lim-Che Lo
Reviews.Content: Good product.  Fast shipment.  EXCELLENT COMMUNICATION AND PACKAGE.  I WILL RECOMMEND TO ANY ONE.  I WILLBUY AGAIN WITHOUT HESITATION.

Reviews.Title: BIGGEST POS LAPTOP!
Reviews.Author: jlk900
Reviews.Content: This laptop is the biggest POS I have ever bought. I purchased the Tai Chi 21 with the i7 processor and I have never been so disappointed in purchasing a laptop. I have not even had the laptop for 60 days and its practically falling apart. I have not dropped the laptop even once and the screen glitches and I have to tap it in order to get it to clear up then it would start doing the same thing within about an hour. I must do this every single time I turn on my laptop. Also, the charging port for my laptop has actually stopped working as well. I have to hold the charger at a certain angle for the laptop to charge and if its not held at that angle then it will not charge. Also, when my laptop is out in dual screen mode it does not work, what I do on my side and what someone else does on their side shows up on the opposite side. I would not even pay 500 for this laptop. This laptop is very overpriced and not worth it at all. This is the biggest mistake I have made.BIGGEST POS LAPTOP EVER!!!!!!! DO NOT PURCHASE!!!!!

Reviews.Title: I like my Taichi, I hate Windows 8 (Windows 8 Rant Ahead)
Reviews.Author: Manda "Manda"
Reviews.Content: So I have been looking for a replacement for my aging Sony Vaio W 10" laptop, one that was a real computer and not another crappy netbook, but I also wanted a small screen like on my current Sony W.I like small screens (with high resolutions) because I like the portability that comes with having a small laptop.  I had been waiting for the non-existent Samsung Sliding PC7, but it never came, I bought the Sony Duo (another sliding form-factor touchscreen) because I was worried that the ASUS would never come (delayed since Oct 2012), but had to return it because of some of the issues it had (see long review at its product page). So now I own the Taichi i7.Pros:Fast, it's an i7 so it better be.Solid, it feels solid despite being the lightest computer I have ever owned.Two LCD screens, which means that there is no elaborate twisting or sliding mechanism to give me both a laptop and a touchpad.  Now I have the best of both worlds without the "prone-to-failure" alternate methods for using one screen in both orientations.Two fast USB 3 ports (not new, but I'm coming from an Atom based old machine so it's fast from my point of view).Hinge is solid and tight at any angle.The screens are HD and the inner one is matte.It comes packaged nicely in a nice box and it made it across 3 continents unbroken.I had no problems out of the box with the dual screen setup with switching between laptop and tablet mode.  I did use the little blue key at first to switch between the two modes, until I realized that simply closing the screen (with the left-side screen lock button in the non-red mode) would switch to tablet mode, and opening it again would switch it back to desktop mode.  (I use the power button for sleep now)It has two cameras, one forward facing and one facing out.The sound is great for such a small laptop.The keyboard is backlit (and brightness is adjustable from keyboard hotkeys).The multi-touchscreen works well, and the included pen works even better.The BIOS has the ability to turn off UEFI protected mode and turn on CSM mode. (for loading other non EFI operating systems like Linux or others).The install of Windows 8 still works even after the protected mode is turned off in the BIOS (the Windows 8 install on the Sony Duo did NOT do this and refused to work in any capacity until UEFI protected mode was turned back on).  So huge plus there for people that want to dual boot (or triple boot) to non-EFI compliant OS'es (the big Linux distros support EFI now, but not the smaller ones).This thing actually can support 3 monitors (with the included video dongle).You can use third party apps to give back some functionality to Windows 8 (Start Clasic, and SearchFX).The 256gb SSD is big and fast.The power-plug seems pretty smooth (it rotates smoothly).  Hopefully it lasts a while.It's all metal and glass and looks nice.It comes with a nice cover/sleeve (not fit to drop it in, but free)Cons:  (most of these cons are related the Windows 8 Home edition that comes on it)It's so light that I worry I'm going to drop it.  (I wish manufactures would design in some areas on the back to grip tablets and ultrabooks better.)It's a fingerprint magnet. (Although my hands could stand to be cleaner I guess)There is no place to store the included pen.It has Windows 8 Home and the upgrade to Pro is $200 from Microsoft ($39 for everyone but people running Win8 Home already, so basically not for anyone buying a new computer).Windows 8 Home doesn't like to let programs access Linux-based SMB mapped drives correctly (oh you can hack the registry to make them work correctly, normally you could use gpedit.msc, but Microsoft removed it from Home versions, so you'll be manually fixing registry entries related to NTLM2 and policies instead).Windows 8 Home doesn't have Hyper-V installed (needs Pro now), so forget about running XP mode or an XP emulation without using a third party program (or paying $200 to Microsoft for Pro).There is no restore DVD or USB drive, and it's a Home version of Windows that doesn't let you properly make one from the software included in Windows.  There is also no ASUS program to make one.  I had to boot into Linux and "dd"ed a copy of the SSD to a large NTFS formated USB memory stick (the image was a 25gb .gz file, hence the need for a NTFS filesystem).Windows 8 has no way of modifying the priority or deleting stored WiFi connections (short of manually updating the contents of a system .xml file).  So you better hope the order it puts them in is the way you want it. (You can find a quirky 3rd party program that modifies the .xml for you).When you uninstall the included Mcafee, it leaves 5 running programs installed. (I guess uninstall means something different nowadays).The SSD comes with multiple partitions installed (2 EFI, 1 restore, 1 recovery, 1 system boot, 1 for C:, 1 for D: (user data).  This seems excessive, and after installing Linux I now have 10 partitions.There is no start bar (no surprise it is Windows 8), but it is a con.  I tried to use it as is (Windows 8 that is), but I can't, and I advise that if you have high blood pressure that you should have a few drinks prior to using Windows 8 for anything other than clicking on the internet or Facebook, as the risk of stroke increases proportionally with the amount of time you spend trying to use your Windows 8 install for real work.The product key is stored in the bios and you can't see or change it, which means that you can not simply buy Windows 8 Pro and install it clean (it will find and use the Home one stored in the bios), so you have to upgrade, but you can't with a full version key.Mint Linux 14 Xfce installs and works ok (my guess is that all Ubuntu based distros will be the same), all the hardware seems to work except the touch screen and the clickpad mouse, the mouse works, but the nature of a clicking touchpad is different than a normal touchpad and without special software to stabilize the bottom of the touchpad (where the button is under) it is hard to click on small things without the mouse jumping about while pressing down.  ASUS could release some support files for Linux related to the clickpad and touchscreen that would make the experience better for us Linux users. Right now the coolness and useability of the second screen goes away on anything except Windows 8.There is no Pause/Break keyboard key. (this seems to be a trend with most manufactures nowadays)Final:In the end I had to install a lot of 3rd party apps to be able to do the same things I was doing under XP. (Start Clasic, SearchFX, WiFi-Profile-Editor) and then tweak those apps settings.  This has nothing to do with this machine's hardware, but seeing as how it does come with Windows 8, it does belong in its review.  Any machine I would have bought new would have had most of those cons (excluding the ability to make a ASUS Restore USB, I blame ASUS for that failing).I am happy I bought the Taichi, I wish ASUS gave the end user some more operating system choices by releasing drivers for Linux, Windows 7, and since I'm dreaming, Windows XP 64-bit.  The hardware is great from the speakers to the screens, the EFI options in the BIOS will make me look to ASUS for my next laptop purchase (I love choices).  The only real problem with this device is that is comes with Windows 8, but it is up to Microsoft to fix its problems not ASUS.Microsoft Rant:Truth is I would have paid an extra $200 if I could have purchased this with XP on it from the factory and had the same touchscreen and second screen functionality as on Windows 8.  I really truly hate Windows 8, much more than I hated Windows 7.  Windows 8 has all the same problems Windows 7 had with its GUI (once in desktop mode), and then they managed to break everything else with the Modern/Metro interface.  This is a computer, not an XBOX, and I'm not 15.  Microsoft needs to realize that most 15 year old kids may think this interface is great, but they are not the ones with the money, nor do they make the software that makes the world work, so stop making "cool" interfaces and give me back my efficiency.  There is no universe where clicking in a corner, then clicking a magnifying glass, then typing the name of the program I want to run (providing I even know the name), and then clicking on it, is faster than simply clicking an icon in a menu.  Just give me back my Start-menu, File Explorer, Control Panel, and Wifi Manager from XP, at least as a choice.  Fin.UPDATE:  March 5, 2013I still like it, but really hated Windows 8, so after an UEFI/CSM issue, I erased all the partitions, converted the SSD to an MBR from a GPT using a PE (wow that's a lot of acronyms), and then created three 20gb partitions (2 NTFS, 1 EX4) and a put the rest as a big NTFS drive label "DATA".  I used my Technet ISO of Windows 8, converted it to a bootable USB install, upon booting it picked up the product key embedded in the BIOS and I installed on the first partition.  I then tried using my backup of the eSystem (ASUS driver folder on original HD) to reload the now missing drivers and Apps, but it glitched and wouldn't install past a certain point, so I just went to ASUS's website and downloaded all the updated drivers from there (for Windows 8).  After installing the downloaded drivers, a few updates, and a few reboots, everything was back to stock (mostly, and minus some factory crapware), both the screen and touch mouse would switch the way they are supposed to.  I then proceed to install Mint Linux XFCE 14, it went in perfectly and grub2 listed both Linux and Win8, and both would boot great.  I then installed Windows XP 64 SP2, after slip-streaming the AHCI and chipset TXTMODE driver into the install disk with nLite )and removed all the unnecessary Windows crap and services).  The creating of the XP disk took 3 tries to get the right version of the AHCI real-mode and TXTmode drivers installed, but afterwards it installed quickly (albeit in 640x480 resolution).  Finding the XP-64 drivers on ASUS's website wasn't going to happen, but I found the Intel HD-4000, Intel Centrino Advanced-N 6235 (Wifi), Bluetooth, 7 Series Chipset, and AHCI SATA drivers on Intel's website, and that got me pretty far. It's still a work in progress to find all the drivers but I think it's possible.  I should also note that Windows XP took control of the booting and only would boot itself, and because it wasn't installed on "C:" it took moving XP boot files, repairing Windows 8, and re-installing Grub2 and some manual grub config file creations to get it back to using Grub2 to select between the 3 operating system choices, but it is possible.  I almost have what I wanted, a Windows XP replacement for my old Sony that can also be used as a tablet.UPDATE:  Sept 5, 2013I still like it, the battery is lasting a little less, but the hinge has given up the ghost.  It will hold near the end of travel in either direction but not in a position that is at the "normal viewing angle", it just drops back a bit.  I can't really tell if the hinge is loose inside or if the spring is worn out.  I'll have to try contacting Asus to see what they want me to do.

Reviews.Title: not in proper working condition
Reviews.Author: Chihuahua
Reviews.Content: Though the laptop software functioned according to my standards and to the claimed specifications, the hardware did not work so well. The battery did not charge while plugged to AC power for the 48 hours that I had the laptop. The product description claimed it would be working at factory standards after a seller refurbish and it was not. As the laptop was refurbished, the manufacturer warranty was void, and thus my only recourse was to return the product for a refund/replacement.

Reviews.Title: Wish I would have bought a Mac
Reviews.Author: pexring
Reviews.Content: I bought this laptop with the i7 over 4 months ago.  I hate it worse every day.  The software is glitchy so the screen changing from front to back works when it feels like.  I've rolled back the software, which helps but creates other issues.  But how hard can it be for the manufacturer to fix that issue?This laptop doesn't play nice with Windows 8.1.  My main goal in purchasing this computer was to edit large (RAW) picture files.  It fails miserably at it.  The laptop just crawls.  The 3-year-old computer that this computer replaced will process pictures faster than this thing.  Plus the graphic card or Windows 8.1 or something will blow out the red's or blues.  It only appears on the screen, but terribly annoying.  I use the latest versions of Lightroom and Elements when editing pictures.The dual screen is pretty much pointless because it's too heavy to use as a tablet.  When you do use it as a tablet, the edges are sharp and uncomfortable to hold and the case you can buy makes it even worse.  And, again, when you do want to flip it to tablet mode, you have to fiddle and fiddle with the software to make it work.I paid almost a $1000 for this piece of crap.  I wish I had my money back!!!!

Reviews.Title: DONT BUY POOR QUALITY PRODUCT
Reviews.Author: Castell9000
Reviews.Content: Asus doesn't use Gorilla Glass. Buyer be warned, the screen will crack with usual use. Mine just did. No drop no falls. No damage to the machine and the screen is cracked. Asus will not help.Please note that unlike the thousands of phones, and tablets that use Gorilla glass Asus doesn't use it. The top screen is exposed and will break. The only other option is to buy an ADH warranty, wait each time to ship the product and wait for it to get fixed.Save your money and either buy a Surface Pro, $300 cheaper or a Lenovo Yoga pad. Not much use for the dual screen any way.Wish could return it, could not do it,.

Reviews.Title: Very Dissapointed!!
Reviews.Author: Ed
Reviews.Content: The touch screen didn't work out of the box....when I finally got it to work there was a 1 inch strip across the touch screen that wouldn't respond to any touch.  The pen didn't work, but didn't have it long enough to see if it came with dead batteries.  Returned it the next day.  Very disappointed.  Really wanted this form factor to work.  Maybe I'll try it again when/if the next version comes out.  have to give Amazon credit for handling the return quickly and painlessly.  Should get my refund credited in a couple of days.

Reviews.Title: PLEASE READ BEFORE YOU BUY ANY ASUS
Reviews.Author: ken Jones
Reviews.Content: When I was looking for a convertible Ultra-book I had been using the Asus slate and had the Tiachi on my shortlist thinking it was a step-up I was also looking at the Surface and the Leveno they were all around the same price and had roughly the same specs. WHAT MADE ME CHOOSE ASUS! Was their Support sales pitch the same one they are using today and I bought into it in a big way I mean just read their promo on this VIP support and year of ADP added in with a special dedicated support line just for Tiachi users this all still sounds good as I’m typing this out eight months later. Now here’s some truth The very things that made this look like a great deal are FALSE ADVERTISING what they don’t show on slick Asus designed sales page is <THE ACCEDENTAL DAMAGE PLAN IS A SINGLE USE PLAN>!! I challenge you to find that on this sales page on Amazon. Now about that VIP support they do send you a little card with the unit with a support number another great empty feeling of security, they do answer the phone fairly quick and speak English they won’t do much but they will tell you that in a language you understand, so there’s that. They also make a big deal, when selling you this line about their VIP support that if you have a problem Asus will use a next business day currier and they will come pickup and then fix or replace and return to your door a working computer and hey this all sounds great hell it made me spend like 1,000 on this 8 months ago except when I tried all this alleged service it didn’t work out so well.let me describe what happened to my computer I keep it next to my recliner sitting on a TV tray plugged in, And in like February this year I was running the vacuum and must have bumped it or something and it fell on the tray then hit the carpet all from a height of let’s say 2.5 ft. at most , well things happen I checked it out all seamed well and went on with life. About 2 weeks later I woke up to find my computer off, this was alarming but I started trying to get it to start, no luck so I thought back to that fall and reached for my special VIP Tiachi support card and called them up from here on it’s a sad story, there wasn’t much trouble shooting to be done since it was not turning on but I have the VIP support so I’m expecting that door to door thing to kick in, well my VIP support tech is telling me that’s not the case and I would need to box it up and send the thing back and forget door to door He is telling I will need to pay the shipping to a depot and expect 2 weeks before I hear anything, now this is not sounding VIP or anything close to what made me buy this special unit, so I ask for a supervisor thinking this support guy just doesn’t know the whole VIP deal while waiting I bring up the amazon page on my phone just to be sure I am not insane and no it still says door to door VIP special support and a year of ADP, about this time the supervisor comes on and says the same thing the underling said send it back at your cost, so I explain the reason I bought the Tiachi and that I wasn’t feeling the VIP love and I literally had to send him to Asus’s own page telling me all of what I’m saying is exactly what’s on their support page, so during the long wait I looked at the ADP page not for this unit but another and it says it’s A SINGLE USE PLAN !! this is confirmed to me by the supervisor by this point I am a little upset but I had remembered that it was plugged in when it took it giant leap of 2 feet on to the carpet and sure enough the light was off on the power supply I explained this and asked for a new supply and that this not be used as my one use ADP I was newly made aware I had been hosed into, that was also a big negative he then came up with he would send me a rma and again in up to 2 weeks I could find out if it was the supply but should they find it was the power and not the fall I would be charged for the new supply and the shipping both ways I asked for names and declined. I ordered a supply from amazon and that was the issue. I then opened a BBB complaint against Asus and after 3 months of back and forth their position has not changed this can all be seen on BBB.org I was also told I wasn’t to publicly recite their response when I said I would yell this to anyone who would listen and didn’t agree to any non-disclosure Asus cut off commutation. So if anyone has read all this keep shopping or at least know that Asus actively engages in DECIPTIVE BUSINESS PRACTICES and FALSE ADVERTISING yet here the same units are being sold by Amazon using the lies that made me sorry I ever heard the name Taichi. Again this is all public record on [...] along with the other thousands of complaints, how Amazon can let this go on I really don’t know..The style of the Taichi line is very good it defiantly has made people ask who makes your laptop- So it does look goodAs for the  functionality there are some drawbacks after 8 months of use some are glaring some are just annoying  from a function standpoint one of the main reasons I went with Asus over the other hybrid convertible ultrabooks was the stylus it was important to me I use one note a lot and also use a stylus to draw diagrams for my work. I had been using the Asus Ep121 slate it had its issues but overall performed well when it worked but that used a Wacom stylus and that is leaps and bounds above this- First it takes a AAAA battery but that’s ok if it worked well, but it does not half the time it won’t engage and when it does it’s hardly accurate ,but once you get used to its flaws you can make it do what needs done, just plan on erasing a lot and starting over. Now on to the screen’s you can watch a movie or you tube ect on the touch side it’s a nice clear picture of course with only 4 gigs of ram and a underpowered processor along with the integrated Intel video card you get pretty much what you would expect, and for the inner side screen in laptop mode it’s just plain bad it has some kind of coating on it that makes everything look almost milky it’s good for word-processing and other business apps in fact it’s the only way you can use most apps, even with apps that have touch support they don’t work right with Taichi’s touch so get used to laptop mode for work but you will also have to get an external mouse the touchpad on this thing will drive you insane they tried to make the touchpad like it was a touchscreen and it didn’t work out pinch and zoom and Asus’s own shortcut’s via touchpad are enough to make you want a refund but you can tweak it and get some use but hey no big deal most laptop touch’s suck. The last point on function I will talk about is power and battery and this was another selling point for me seeing the Centrino name again gave me high hopes but it was not to be you can expect 2 hours of outside on a nice day work time just sit in the shade because you will have a lot of glare or dark issues on either screen.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful piece of crap
Reviews.Author: Mike Akrish
Reviews.Content: The most beautiful laptop I have had but It hardly works.  It can't be updated to 8.1 without doing some significant manual updates and then there is no guarantee of full functionality.

Reviews.Title: Not compatible with 8.1
Reviews.Author: Whiskey
Reviews.Content: I have this since feb 2013I would loved to be proved wrong on this.But my wife tried to do an upgrade to 8.1 and the ultrabook blew up (not literally)So she had to rollback to 8,which for many reasons I think is CRAPPY.!!Have not tried to dual boot it with Linux yet.Also the memory cannot be upgraded from 4 GB. I kinda knew it before buying it but I still did (Against all the principles that I stand for) just to make my wife happy.3 stars just because my wife seems to like it.

Reviews.Title: Paid for the i7 and was shipped the i5
Reviews.Author: michael hebert
Reviews.Content: Buyer beware. I was very excited to order this computer and opted for the operating system costing several hundred dollars more. Dum dum dumb! Received an i5. I noticed that it was processing slowly right out of the box and looked down to see the dreaded i5 sticker glaring back at me with it's middle finger extended. Amazon customer service was nice enough to offer a refund but I wasn't offered compensation for the time and effort lost getting the computer from ups (they didn't leave it at the door as I expected) and the refund will only hit my account 3-5 business days after the receive the product back which could end up taking 3 weeks according to the rep I spoke with. Mostly, I'm dissapointed that I don't have the computer I was highly anticipating and I worry that other consumers wouldn't have even noticed that they were shipped the wrong item. So, I think the computer is probably fine but watch your order closely.Long-time Amazon fan,Michael

Reviews.Title: disappointed
Reviews.Author: Dandachi
Reviews.Content: I was so excited to get this computer specially after I watced the videos....but all this exictment truned into disapponitment...it is the worst computer i have ever had.the performance was really horriblesluggish movements---extended periods of unresposiveness..unexpected chnages in the screen mode...small characters...sound system is like old radio barely able to hear...unable to access the computer because of stupid change in the caharcters ...everything was below expectation,i was expecting a surprise but it is not...i tried to use it for 1 month hoping that things wil change....but the peroformace was really suboptimal...i returned it and iw ill never buy asus anymore ..Simply I hate it

Reviews.Title: Cool product, horrible OS
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: The laptop itself was sleek, small, and I really liked how it turned into a tablet when closed. However, I couldn't enjoy any of the features of the laptop or tablet because the operating system was such a nightmare. Windows 8 is the least user-friendly interface I have ever encountered. I had read reviews complaining about the lack of a start button, difficulty formatting, etc. But I gave the product a try anyway, hoping that people had just given up too soon. Well, I tried for a week straight to get this tangle of technology to cooperate, with little to no success. I even had my very technically savvy husband take a crack at it, and even he came away frustrated. We really like Asus products, but until Windows comes up with a better OS, I don't see these tablets doing well. We returned ours.

Reviews.Title: excellent and very rare
Reviews.Author: Tsin C. Juan
Reviews.Content: I love the dual screen and very convenient design, it satisfies both my desire for pad and notebook. I don't need to buy extra stand piece like the 10.1 Tab when watch the movie or youtube.  The 11.6 inch screen fit my business bag and not that heavy. Very easy to carry and ready to use. The out looking seems very sharp and stylish. The only concern is battery will last onlyn 5 hrs.  But, I can charge the battery during lunch hour or buy a standby battery.
